J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Chanduram wrote:
>
>> Hi,
>>
>> I am a learner of JUnit, I have this query :
>>
>> How can I write a test method for the following method, is it
>> possible to write testcase for this method using JUnit. If yes, plz
>> help me how to do , else which framework should I use .
>>
>> // How should I create HttpServletRequest parameter and ActionMapping
>> parameters in my JUnit test code.
>
>
> You can use jMock to create a fake HttpServletRequest, giving that
> object the request parameters and servlet path you want.
>
> As for ActionMapping, you can just create one and set its properties.
>
> Once you do those two things, then simply invoke validate() and check
> the return value (ActionErrors) by asking for the list of error
> messages and asserting that it contains the proper ones.
>
> Please ask these questions in the Yahoo! group, because I do not
> always respond quickly and someone else might have a better answer
> than I do.
>
> Good luck.



Chanduram wrote:

I am a learner of JUnit, I have this query :

How can I write a test method for the following method, is it possible
to write testcase for this method using JUnit. If yes, plz help me how
to do , else which framework should I use .

// How should I create HttpServletRequest parameter and ActionMapping
parameters in my JUnit test code.


public ActionErrors validate(
ActionMapping mapping,
HttpServletRequest request)
{
String type = request.getParameter("method");
// Check for mandatory data
ActionErrors errors = new ActionErrors();
//System.out.println("type ==> "+type);
if ((!type.equals("editCancelLogin"))
&& (!type.equals("deleteCancelLogin"))
&& (!type.equals("sendToHubCancelLogin")))
{
if (usrId == null || usrId.equals(""))
{
errors.add("usrId", new ActionError("ap.login.error.invalid"));
return errors;
}
if (pwd == null || pwd.equals(""))
{
errors.add("pwd", new ActionError("ap.login.error.invalid"));
return errors;
}

// Check for valid user name and password
LoginCheck loginCheck = new LoginCheck();
if (!loginCheck.authenticate(usrId, pwd))
{
errors.add(
"invalidlogin",
new ActionError("ap.login.error.invalid"));
return errors;
}
}
return errors;
} // end validate
